HOPKINS WINS GAME
Black and Blue Lacrosse Team
Defeats the Strong Mt. Washington Twelve in Hard-fought
Contest.
In a very hotly con:ested game, the
Hopkins Lacrosse Team defeated the
Mt. Washington twelve by the score
of 5 to 3. The black and blue players
had more endurance than their opponents, and they displayed better stick
work. With the ocception of the first
half of the second session of play, the
winners had things all their own way.
The work of everybody of the Hopkins team was of a gilt-edged order,
and the players seem to have struck
their gait at last. At all times both
the Hopkins attack and defense played in an aggressive manner which
pleased very much the coaches and
the large crowd of alumni present.
Harry Schmeisser said:"The boys are
playing with the ginger that makes
a winning team, and their earnest
manner pleases me more than anything I have seen this season."
Bill Gail and Ed Clary were the
stars on the attach, for Hopkins. They
each shot two goals and played a
steady game throughout the entire
contest. The body checking of Captain Schmeisser was one of the features of the game. Sears played a
fine game before the net, and Keith
was strictly on the job at all times
in his position at cover point.
Lamotte's work for Mt. Washington at point would be hard to beat.
He did more toward holding down
the Hopkins attack than anybody on
the Mountaineers' team. He played‘a
scientific game and exhibited greatest coolness throughout. Matthai was
another star for the Hillmen. The
former Hopkins captain showed that
he has lost none of his old-time
speed.
The teams were pretty evenly
matched at the beginning of the contest, but after the play had been under way for some time several of the
Mountaineers were all in. Hulburt
then shot the first goal by some fast
play. Clary followed soon after with
another, and the half ended with the
score 2 to o in Hopkins' favor.
During the intermission between
the halves the Hillmen revived considerably, and they played such a desperate game for a time after the whistle blew that the Hopkins players
were momentarily swamped. The
'varsity soon steadied down, but not
before the Mountaineers had scored
three goals. Gail did not let the losers have the pleasure of remaining

PSYCHOLOGISTS'
CONVENTION
The convention of the Psychologists which was held here last week
brought many prominent men to the
University. lhe convention was arranged largely by Dr. Watson, and
was held in the Psychological Laboratory. Among those present were
the following:
Prof. E. B. Titchener, Cornell University.
Prof. Hugo Munsterburg, Harvard
University.
Prof. Joseph Jastrow, University
of Wisconsin.
Prof. Edwin B. Holt, Harvard
University.
Prof. Robert M. Yerkes, Harvard
University.
Prof. Arthur H. Pierce, Smith College.
Prof. Howard C. Warren, Princeton University.
Prof. John W. Baird, Clark University.
President E. C. Sanford, Clark
College.
Prof. C. E. Ferree, Bryn Mawr
College.
Prof. Samuel P. Hayes, Mt.'Holyoke College.
Professor Watson, J. H. U.
Prof. Dunlop, J. H. U.
Professor Vaughan, New York
Normal School.
Prof. Edw. F. Buchner, J. H. U.
Dean Griffin, J. H. U.
Prof. Shepherd I. Franz, Government Insane Hospital, Washington,
D. d.
Prof. Edw. L. Thorndike, Teachers'
College, Columbia University, New
York.
HOPKINS BEATS
DICKINSON
In a well-contested track and field
event Saturday the Hopkins team defeated Dickinson by 63 to 49 points.
Dickinson had the better of the field
events, but the University proved
much stronger on the track.
Lee won the mile, Hunter the iooyard dash, Morton the 120-yard hurdle, Fulton the 44o-yard dash, Reeside the two-mile run, and Hunter the
220-yard dash. Stollenwerck was second in the ioo-yard dash and in the
220-yard hurdle.
Horrax and ,Lee starred for the
University in the field events.
in the lead for any length of time.
He succeeded in caging the ball from
a very difficult angle, and thus tied
the score. Hulburt made sure of the
game by shooting another goal. Clary
and Gail each made another tally before the end of the game.

THE NEWS-LETTER. April 25, 1910.

The News-Letter
April

HOPKINS WINS GAME
Black and Blue Lacrosse Team
Defeats the Strong Mt. Washington Twelve in Hard-fought
Contest.
In a very hotly con:ested game, the
Hopkins Lacrosse Team defeated the
Mt. Washington twelve by the score
of 5 to 3. The black and blue players
had more endurance than their opponents, and they displayed better stick
work. With the ocception of the first
half of the second session of play, the
winners had things all their own way.
The work of everybody of the Hopkins team was of a gilt-edged order,
and the players seem to have struck
their gait at last. At all times both
the Hopkins attack and defense played in an aggressive manner which
pleased very much the coaches and
the large crowd of alumni present.
Harry Schmeisser said:"The boys are
playing with the ginger that makes
a winning team, and their earnest
manner pleases me more than anything I have seen this season."
Bill Gail and Ed Clary were the
stars on the attach, for Hopkins. They
each shot two goals and played a
steady game throughout the entire
contest. The body checking of Captain Schmeisser was one of the features of the game. Sears played a
fine game before the net, and Keith
was strictly on the job at all times
in his position at cover point.
Lamotte's work for Mt. Washington at point would be hard to beat.
He did more toward holding down
the Hopkins attack than anybody on
the Mountaineers' team. He played‘a
scientific game and exhibited greatest coolness throughout. Matthai was
another star for the Hillmen. The
former Hopkins captain showed that
he has lost none of his old-time
speed.
The teams were pretty evenly
matched at the beginning of the contest, but after the play had been under way for some time several of the
Mountaineers were all in. Hulburt
then shot the first goal by some fast
play. Clary followed soon after with
another, and the half ended with the
score 2 to o in Hopkins' favor.
During the intermission between
the halves the Hillmen revived considerably, and they played such a desperate game for a time after the whistle blew that the Hopkins players
were momentarily swamped. The
'varsity soon steadied down, but not
before the Mountaineers had scored
three goals. Gail did not let the losers have the pleasure of remaining

Price, 3 cents per copy
PSYCHOLOGISTS'
CONVENTION
The convention of the Psychologists which was held here last week
brought many prominent men to the
University. lhe convention was arranged largely by Dr. Watson, and
was held in the Psychological Laboratory. Among those present were
the following:
Prof. E. B. Titchener, Cornell University.
Prof. Hugo Munsterburg, Harvard
University.
Prof. Joseph Jastrow, University
of Wisconsin.
Prof. Edwin B. Holt, Harvard
University.
Prof. Robert M. Yerkes, Harvard
University.
Prof. Arthur H. Pierce, Smith College.
Prof. Howard C. Warren, Princeton University.
Prof. John W. Baird, Clark University.
President E. C. Sanford, Clark
College.
Prof. C. E. Ferree, Bryn Mawr
College.
Prof. Samuel P. Hayes, Mt.'Holyoke College.
Professor Watson, J. H. U.
Prof. Dunlop, J. H. U.
Professor Vaughan, New York
Normal School.
Prof. Edw. F. Buchner, J. H. U.
Dean Griffin, J. H. U.
Prof. Shepherd I. Franz, Government Insane Hospital, Washington,
D. d.
Prof. Edw. L. Thorndike, Teachers'
College, Columbia University, New
York.
HOPKINS BEATS
DICKINSON
In a well-contested track and field
event Saturday the Hopkins team defeated Dickinson by 63 to 49 points.
Dickinson had the better of the field
events, but the University proved
much stronger on the track.
Lee won the mile, Hunter the iooyard dash, Morton the 120-yard hurdle, Fulton the 44o-yard dash, Reeside the two-mile run, and Hunter the
220-yard dash. Stollenwerck was second in the ioo-yard dash and in the
220-yard hurdle.
Horrax and ,Lee starred for the
University in the field events.
in the lead for any length of time.
He succeeded in caging the ball from
a very difficult angle, and thus tied
the score. Hulburt made sure of the
game by shooting another goal. Clary
and Gail each made another tally before the end of the game.

THE NEWS-LETTER. April 25, 1910.
